main.description: Official WHO SMART Guidelines website - Standards-based, machine-readable, adaptive, requirements-based, and testable guidelines

source_code.description: WHO GitHub repositories including SMART Guidelines implementations

ProductOverview.Summary: WHO SMART Guidelines are standards-based, machine-readable, adaptive, requirements-based, and testable guidelines that can be implemented in digital health systems.
ProductOverview.Description: WHO SMART Guidelines transform traditional clinical guidelines into digital formats that can be directly implemented in health information systems. They use standardized data models, clinical decision support rules, and interoperability standards to ensure consistent implementation across different digital health platforms. The guidelines cover various health areas including maternal and child health, infectious diseases, and non-communicable diseases.
ProductOverview.PrimaryFunctionality: Digital clinical guidelines with standards-based implementation and clinical decision support
ProductOverview.Users: Health system developers, implementers, healthcare providers, and digital health architects

Reach.SummaryOfReach: WHO SMART Guidelines have been implemented in multiple countries and digital health platforms globally, supporting standardized clinical care delivery.

Maturity.SummaryOfMaturity: All maturity model assessments are self-reported by the funded organization leading the development of the global good.

Community.DescriptionOfCommunity: WHO SMART Guidelines are developed through a collaborative process involving WHO technical teams, global health experts, and digital health implementers.

HostAnchorOrganization.name: World Health Organization
HostAnchorOrganization.description: United Nations specialized agency for international public health

Events.description: Regular technical working groups and implementation workshops
Events.schedule: Quarterly technical meetings and annual implementation workshops

Policies.Description: WHO follows established governance and policy frameworks for guideline development and digital health standards.

Governance.description: WHO governance structure and decision-making processes

TermsOfUse.description: WHO terms of use and copyright information

PrivacyPolicy.description: WHO privacy policy and data protection

InclusiveDesign.Description: WHO SMART Guidelines are designed to be inclusive and accessible across different health system contexts and technical capabilities.
InclusiveDesign.UserInput: Global health expert input and implementer feedback inform guideline development
InclusiveDesign.OfflineSupport: Guidelines can be implemented in various connectivity environments

EnvironmentalImpact.LowCarbon: Digital guidelines reduce paper waste and support sustainable health system operations

TotalCostOfOwnership.Description: WHO SMART Guidelines are freely available, with implementation costs related to digital health system development and integration.

Sustainability.Description: WHO SMART Guidelines are sustained through WHO's ongoing technical work and global health partnerships.
